key_points: A Texas gun store, Saddle River Range, announced a 'not guilty' sale following Kyle Rittenhouse's acquittal.
The sale, promoted via text message to customers, includes deals on firearms, optics, bags, and gun parts.
The promotion, highlighting the acquittal, has received mixed reactions from the public.
Owner Thomas Bolsch said the sale celebrated the Second Amendment and self-defense rights, not the loss of life.
Customer reactions varied, with some expressing disappointment over the store capitalizing on a sensitive situation.
Despite criticism, Bolsch claims most customer feedback has been supportive and positive.
Bolsch stated he stands by his message and would not change the promotion.
Dr. James Dixon, president of the NAACP Houston Branch, emphasized the need for sensitivity in promotional messages.
Dixon noted the broader context of protests against racial injustice following the shooting of Jacob Blake.
The store's promotion has sparked a conversation about the intersection of business practices and societal issues.
spokespersons: Dr. James Dixon (President, NAACP Houston Branch)
